articles.headline: Russia Becomes a Magnet for U.S. Fast-Food Chains
articles.snippet: As the middle class emerges in Russia, so has a wider array of American fast food.
articles.abstract: As the middle class emerges in Russia, so has a wider array of American fast food.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Earlier in his career, Christopher Wynne put his Russian expertise to work researching arms proliferation for the American government. Now he’s engaged in geopolitics of another sort: deploying American fast food for the emerging Russian middle class.

articles.headline: Tiny Camera Performs Like a Pro
articles.snippet: Two new cameras from Sony and Olympus make breakthroughs in the competition for better pictures from smaller cameras.
articles.abstract: Two new cameras from Sony and Olympus make breakthroughs in the competition for better pictures from smaller cameras.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 20 years, the digital camera makers are finally giving the world what it really wants: spectacular, professional-looking photos — from a tiny camera. There’s only one problem with this new category: nobody knows what to call it.

articles.headline: Rivals in G.O.P. Struggle to Woo Bush’s Donors
articles.snippet: No Republican presidential candidate has yet shown the broad appeal that drew the party’s donor establishment to George W. Bush’s first run.
articles.abstract: No Republican presidential candidate has yet shown the broad appeal that drew the party’s donor establishment to George W. Bush’s first run.
articles.lead_paragraph: The calls come at least once a week these days, with growing urgency: friends of the Republican presidential candidates, aides to the candidates, and often the candidates themselves, wondering if Al Hoffman Jr. might be ready to lend a hand.

articles.headline: Large Banks in Europe Struggle With Weak Bonds
articles.snippet: Investors fear that banks’ vulnerability in Italy and Spain mean Europe’s bid to control its debt has come up short.
articles.abstract: Investors fear that banks’ vulnerability in Italy and Spain mean Europe’s bid to control its debt has come up short.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ever since the European debt crisis began, the risk of contagion — of problems spreading from smaller countries to bigger ones, like Italy and Spain — has worried government officials and investors.

articles.headline: Worry Grows Over Delays in F.A.A. Pay
articles.snippet: Airport operators said that a prolonged delay in restoring federal funding for construction projects would eventually endanger airport safety and lead to more passenger delays.
articles.abstract: Airport operators said that a prolonged delay in restoring federal funding for construction projects would eventually endanger airport safety and lead to more passenger delays.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Airport operators said Wednesday that a prolonged delay in restoring federal funds for airport construction projects would eventually endanger airport safety and lead to more passenger delays.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: New Jockeying in Congress for Next Phase in Budget Fight
articles.snippet: Congressional leaders have two weeks to name panel members to the “supercommittee” that is supposed to recommend at least $1.5 trillion of additional deficit-reduction measures.
articles.abstract: Congressional leaders have two weeks to name panel members to the “supercommittee” that is supposed to recommend at least $1.5 trillion of additional deficit-reduction measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans and Democrats maneuvered for advantage on Wednesday in the next battle over federal spending, trying to influence the choice of members and frame the agenda for a powerful “supercommittee” that is supposed to recommend at least $1.5 trillion of additional deficit reduction measures.

articles.headline: Even Marked Up, Luxury Goods Fly Off Shelves
articles.snippet: While retailers selling to average Americans are holding near fire sales, a recovery at the top is helping high-end retailers to sell out of their most expensive items.
articles.abstract: While retailers selling to average Americans are holding near fire sales, a recovery at the top is helping high-end retailers to sell out of their most expensive items.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nordstrom has a waiting list for a Chanel sequined tweed coat with a $9,010 price. Neiman Marcus has sold out in almost every size of Christian Louboutin “Bianca” platform pumps, at $775 a pair. Mercedes-Benz said it sold more cars last month in the United States than it had in any July in five years.

articles.headline: Stocks Plunge on Fears of Global Turmoil
articles.snippet: American indexes fell around 5 percent as new data heightened fears that the United States may be headed toward a double-dip recession and that Europe’s debt crisis could widen.
articles.abstract: American indexes fell around 5 percent as new data heightened fears that the United States may be headed toward a double-dip recession and that Europe’s debt crisis could widen.
articles.lead_paragraph: What began as a weak day in the stock markets ended in the worst rout in more than two years, as investors dumped stocks amid anxiety that both Europe and the United States were failing to fix deepening economic problems.
